HOWARD RELEASES 4-PART PLAN
By MARK REUTTER
Procedures to discover whether "widespread dissatisfaction"
with the governing system exists
at Homewood were released late
yesterday by the faculty Committee on Governance.
Their plan is four-fold: to
conduct in-depth opinion _samplings of faculty members and graduate students, to query members of
campus Committees, to present
an open forum on Governance
and to distribute an undergraduate

poll on the issue.
According to the Governance
Committee's chairman and spokesman, Dr. Woodford Howard of
Political Science, their report
should be completed by mid-APril.
The other Committee members
are Dr. John Baldwin of History,
Dr. Maurice Bessman of Biology,
Dr. Jan Minkowski of Electrical
Engineering and Dr. Jerome Perlstein of Chemistry.
Except for the open forum,
all the Committee's meetings will
be closed. Howard stated that the
forum has not been scheduled
yet and the poll will be conducted
after there has been more discussion of the Governance issue.
Suggestions Welcome

DR. MAURICE BESSMAN

Besides future meetings with
Homewood faculty-student committees, it was decided that time
would be set aside to confidentially listen to student complaints
with the present system. "Any
suggestions or communications,"
said Howard, "would be welcomed."
If sufficient dissatisfaction is
found with the present system,
the Howard Committee is charged

"to recommend to the Academic
Council the composition of and
the charge to a body to propose
appropriate revisions in the mechanisms for policy- formulation."
Dr. Howard has already rejected the notion that dissatisfaction would ever be widespread
on campus. "In all political circumstances, there are only about
three percent of the population
that plays a more active role than
just voting," Howard observed.
"What we're out to find is what
type of dissatisfaction is here, its
intensity and what priorities
should be set up."
There are three major problems, Howard asserted, that his
committee must sort out in the
following week. He stated that
there is "a multiplicity of interests here, including those of
the junior faculty members, the
senior faculty and the research
assistants," as well as the students.
How to increase each segment's
representation and access to the
decision-making process, Howard
related, will be explored by the
Governance Committee.

Baltimore's rat problem was the subject of an AWARE meeting last Tuesday

By GEORGE KLOPFER

The Howard Proposals
After a month of rather mystifying deliberations, the Howard Committee has publicly released a series of concrete proposals as to how it will
delve into the complicated problems of Homewood governance. It is now
hoped that this evidence of the Committee's good faith will dispel whatever mistrust and hostility is still left among the student body.
Despite the fact that the Committee did take so long in preparing
its first major statement, it now appears that the road is open for a rapid
and effective exploration of the true feelings this campus has toward the
present system of governance. This is the only way in which ultimate
decisions concerning changes can be made.
Of the Committee's three-pronged exploration, two parts are immediately, understandable and to be commended. If the issues are ever to be
1?rought out into the open and analyzed, the only reasonable method is
through an open forum. And, since any forum will only draw a limited
audience, it is also necessary to conduct a large-scale poll of all sections of
the campus. The faculty has made it clear that it will not accept the cries
of a few as an indication of a mass movement; they, therefore, must be
presented with the cold facts.
The Committee's third approach—the confidential, in-depth sampling
of selected members of the community—has, however, not been adequately justified. There is no question that in-depth questioning is as important
as mass-polling, especially as it will require a greater amount of responsible
reasoning on both sides. Why, though, is it to be kept confidential? What
does either the committee or its witnesses have that must be kept secret
from the rest of the community? The only result of such an action is to
open up the committee to charges of bias and weighting of some testimony
over others.
With the exception of this one reservation—and we hope that the
committee will reconsider its decision in the spirit of handling the entire
matter openly and candidly—prospects for a rapid and satisfactory conclusion to this first step are looking much better.
In the future, working on the premise that "widespread dissatisfaction" will be found on the Homewood campus, the Howard Committee
should quickly take steps to help formulate a second general committee
on governance. This committee, composed of students and administrators
as well as faculty, is where the testimony from the Howard Committee
should be examined, and the alternatives for Hopkins governance should
emerge.
However, the future is dependent now on student interest in improving the governing system. This means enough interest to fill out
questionnaires, attend meetings and most of all think about the issues.
The myriad of questions on governance are not easy. Would the muchadvocated University Senate solve Hopkins' problems or would it degenerate society? Should governance changes be aimed at the Academic
Council or should the department's autonomy be weakened? In what
proportion should power be delegated to each segment of the University
and how should the representatives of each be chosen? These plus many
more questions must be answered.
Dr. Howard seems willing to push for meaningful changes in the
present system, but he believes, and rightly so, that students should express their concern in the matter. In this, only the students can reply,
making the following weeks critical in more ways than preparing for midterms.

By GEORGE KLOPFER

The Howard Proposals
After a month of rather mystifying deliberations, the Howard Committee has publicly released a series of concrete proposals as to how it will
delve into the complicated problems of Homewood governance. It is now
hoped that this evidence of the Committee's good faith will dispel whatever mistrust and hostility is still left among the student body.
Despite the fact that the Committee did take so long in preparing
its first major statement, it now appears that the road is open for a rapid
and effective exploration of the true feelings this campus has toward the
present system of governance. This is the only way in which ultimate
decisions concerning changes can be made.
Of the Committee's three-pronged exploration, two parts are immediately, understandable and to be commended. If the issues are ever to be
1?rought out into the open and analyzed, the only reasonable method is
through an open forum. And, since any forum will only draw a limited
audience, it is also necessary to conduct a large-scale poll of all sections of
the campus. The faculty has made it clear that it will not accept the cries
of a few as an indication of a mass movement; they, therefore, must be
presented with the cold facts.
The Committee's third approach—the confidential, in-depth sampling
of selected members of the community—has, however, not been adequately justified. There is no question that in-depth questioning is as important
as mass-polling, especially as it will require a greater amount of responsible
reasoning on both sides. Why, though, is it to be kept confidential? What
does either the committee or its witnesses have that must be kept secret
from the rest of the community? The only result of such an action is to
open up the committee to charges of bias and weighting of some testimony
over others.
With the exception of this one reservation—and we hope that the
committee will reconsider its decision in the spirit of handling the entire
matter openly and candidly—prospects for a rapid and satisfactory conclusion to this first step are looking much better.
In the future, working on the premise that "widespread dissatisfaction" will be found on the Homewood campus, the Howard Committee
should quickly take steps to help formulate a second general committee
on governance. This committee, composed of students and administrators
as well as faculty, is where the testimony from the Howard Committee
should be examined, and the alternatives for Hopkins governance should
emerge.
However, the future is dependent now on student interest in improving the governing system. This means enough interest to fill out
questionnaires, attend meetings and most of all think about the issues.
The myriad of questions on governance are not easy. Would the muchadvocated University Senate solve Hopkins' problems or would it degenerate society? Should governance changes be aimed at the Academic
Council or should the department's autonomy be weakened? In what
proportion should power be delegated to each segment of the University
and how should the representatives of each be chosen? These plus many
more questions must be answered.
Dr. Howard seems willing to push for meaningful changes in the
present system, but he believes, and rightly so, that students should express their concern in the matter. In this, only the students can reply,
making the following weeks critical in more ways than preparing for midterms.

have been relatively calm through the
last week the, storm is far from over:
An Eastern High School teacher has been
suspended and more than a hundred students arrested in various protests are
still awaiting verdicts.
Eight Eastern girls whose arrest more
than two weeks ago sparked the school
disturbances have been freed., The Baltimore Grand Jury reversed its indictments and handed down dismissal orders.
States Attorney Charles Moylan, who
convinced the Grand Jury to reverse itself, said that the procedure was without
precedent.
In a related development, the school
board appealed to Moylan for a recommendation to municipal court judges that
charges against Poly-Western High
School demonstrators be dismissed.For
those cases already tried in the Municipal Court, the board urged Moylan to
request that they be reopened and dismissed.
The school board did not,however,request judicial amnesty for students who
were arrested for acts which probably
were unrelated to the demonstrations.
For example, Troy Lee remained charged with possession of firearms, trespassing and assualting a teacher at
School No. 91.

"Goddamn"
An Eastern High School teacher, Eric
Hallengren, was suspended for using
"profanity" to a vice-principal at a faculty meeting. Hallengren was allegedly
sympathetic to the demands of the black
students, and a faculty meeting was
called, with Superintendent of Schools
Thomas Sheldon attending. At that meeting, the vice-principal charged that Hallengren displayed Black Panther posters,
stirred up the students, and lacked dedication to his teaching responsibilities.
Hallengren, a first-year English
teacher, jumped up and said, "That's a
goddamned lie!" He was suspended; a
public hearing was held at the Department of Education on Thursday.
Also at Eastern, girls representing
the Black Voice group presented the
principal with four new demands, in-

eluding with them criticisms of the present grievance procedure and a demand
for a Black Awareness Day, with an
assembly run by Black Voice.

"No Prejudice"
The new president of the school board,
Attorney Robert L. Karwacki, expressed
his belief in racial equality andhis sympathy with some student demands during
an interview conducted by the Baltimore Afro-American. He said that the
Mayor had met with him to determine
his attitudes on racial questions, and
had been convinced that Karwacki was
not prejudiced.
Karwacki also commented, "I do think
the students have legitimate complaints."
Concerning Dr. Sheldon, he said, "Dr.
Sheldon I find to be fair, intelligent, and
a well-educated man.There's not a racial
cell in his body. Racial prejudice is foreign to him."
Karwacki, however, did not request
judicial amnesty.
